Description: Neck of a glazed composition New Year's flask; cylindrical and terminating with a papyrus capital; incised details of a figure of a crouching ape on the shoulder; chipped and glaze heavily worn.
Curator's comments: Provenance not specified in the Museum register, but certainly from Tell Dafana, according to the context of the item in the list. One of the "many varieties of 'pilgrim bottles' of green or yellow paste, with necks of lotus and palm patterns, some very graceful, and wreathed around the body with very varied patterns" mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 75 § 72. See also London, BM, EA 21779, 21781, 21782, 23755, 23756, 23757, 55345, 55346, Bolton, 1886.28.23.a and b and Boston, MFA, RES.87.146.a- h.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 75 § 72)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.53, p.174, pl.16)
Condition: poor (incomplete - neck only and glaze decayed)
